Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2008 08:37AM djz2003 wrote: I was on a trial hormone blocking drug similar to tamoxifen for 8 1/2 years and then on tamoxifen for 18 months before it failed.  I am now on Arimidex and won't have tests done for several weeks to see if it is working, but I feel so much better than I did on tamoxifen.  My onc says there are many other treatment options.  I have lung and bone mets.
Posts.Title: anyone stable or NED on AIs for a long time? Diana_B Carmelle

Posts.Content: May 25, 2011 09:43AM djz2003 wrote: For me it isn't easier.  I've been dealing with Stage IV mets for 12 1/2 years.  I can look at my radiology reports online from my cancer center...to date I have 98 reports listed for various CT scans, x-rays, PET/CT scans.  I guess having the scans and knowing what is going on is better than the unknown.  I am currently on my 6th anti-estrogen treatment.  It has been six weeks and I have another six to go before a PET scan.  I'm anxious all the time about whether the drug is working.
Posts.Title: Does It Ever Get Easier? NewReality cookie97

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 02:34PM djz2003 wrote: When my husband and I found out the cancer had spread to my lung it was like someone had punched us in the stomach.  We drove home in silence and I cried for days.  I have grown children but I started thinking about what I could leave for them so they would remember me.  I frantically worked making scrapbooks for them starting with their birth through college graduation and I cried over every page I made.  I started thinking about how to plan the end of my life and also started treatment.  Then days went by, weeks went by, months went by and the cancer was stable.  Of course I would freak out every time I had to go for tests (which was every three months).  I felt like I was living my life in three month segments, but I learned to make the most of those in between times.  And the thing that helped me the most...I started doing things for others.  I started volunteering at my church.  Then I started a weekly bible study group and began helping my husband (who is a pastor) in the church office.  Now 10 years later I still think about it often, but I feel like my QOL is good.  I recently started a food ministry at our church to help those in need in our community.  In helping others, I found peace and the strength to keep going.
Posts.Title: How do I cope with mets...anyone want to teach the 101 class?? AlaskaDeb slonedeb

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2008 02:09PM djz2003 wrote: My onc said he hoped to get another 10 years out of tamoxifen.  The trial drug I took for 8 1/2 years was similar to tamoxifen but was supposed to have fewer side effects.  The drug manufacturer, Eli Lilly, decided that this drug didn't work for breast cancer and quit giving it to me.  That is the reason the onc changed me over to tamoxifen.  He said it works in a different way than tamoxifen so he wants to make sure that tamoxifen has failed before he gives me Arimidex.  I spoke with his office yesterday and he has agreed to ordering a PET/CT scan in March when I go in for my next visit.  Perhaps that will tell more about what's going on with my eye.  Debbie
Posts.Title: Anyone with Horner's Syndrome? djz2003 Kerrilyn

Posts.Content: djz2003 wrote: I was diagnosed with bc in 1985, lumpectomy and radiation.  Had recurrence in 1987, mastectomy and radiation.  Had recurrence in 1998, lung mets.  I received a trial drug at MDA Cancer Center in Houston for 8 1/2 years and was then switched to Tamoxifen after the trial ended.  I've been on Tamoxifen for 1 1/2 years.  The lung tumor has been stable since 1998.  The onc thinks I also have a few bone mets on several ribs that show up in bone scan.  Two weeks ago I noticed while putting on makeup that my pupils were unevenly dialated.  After doing some research online, I knew this was not a good sign.  I contacted my onc who suggested I go to an opthamologist.  The opthamologist told me I had something called Horner's Syndrome which is nerve damage to the nerve that controls your pupil dilation and holds up your eyelid.  He really scared me by telling me I could have a brain tumor or worse.  After having a CT scan of head, neck, chest, nothing new showed up.  My onc says to come back in two months for another chest CT scan to see if anything has changed.  Until then he wants me to stay on Tamoxifen. Even though I am postmenopausal, he wants to hold off on giving me Arimedex.  Has anyone else experienced Horner's Syndrome...symtoms are droopy eyelid and unevenly dilated pupils caused by compression somewhere on the sympathetic nerve which goes from your brain down your spine across your chest up the neck and to the pupil and lid?  Debbie Dx 12/12/1998, IDC, <1cm, Stage IV, 0/12 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Anyone with Horner's Syndrome? djz2003 Kerrilyn

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2011 12:10PM djz2003 wrote: I've had bone mets diagnosed 12/98.  Started in sacrum and has slowly spread over the years to a few ribs, few spots on spine.  Also have spot in lung lymph node and two small spots under skin that are stable.  I've been on anti-estrogen drugs during this time but my choices are running out.  Probably will be on Xeloda next if any further progression shows up. My onc gave me two years in 1998..he was wrong.  I think 2-5 years is a standard response.  They have no idea! Debbie
Posts.Title: How long have you had bone mets? Foxlairfrm cmhartley

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 01:53PM djz2003 wrote: I had immediate breast reconstruction in 1986 after a mastectomy with expander and silicone implant.  In 1998 I was diagnosed with lung mets.  The onc told me I probably had two years.  Well, so far it has been ten years and the lung mets have been stable.  Over the years my reconstructed breast with the implant became hard, flat and was causing discomfort so I decided to have TRAM surgery and have the implants taken out.  That was 18 months ago.  I told my onc what I wanted to do and he told me it was my life and if that's how I wanted to spend it (dealing with the recovery period for the TRAM) it was OK with him.  So, I did it.  It relieved my discomfort and made me feel better and my insurance paid for it.  I still have not had the nipple tattoo, but will probably have it done soon.  I was a little apprehensive about having the surgery because I have reduced lung capacity in the side with mets, but the surgery took 6 hours and everything was fine.  Nobody has a right to take away our hope.
Posts.Title: mets and reconstruction BethNY Maryiz

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2008 08:50AM djz2003 wrote: I also agree with the others.  I had a recurrence of breast cancer after 12 years with mets to the lung.  My cancer is ER+.  I go to a major cancer center for treatment and my onc. said that estrogen blocking therapy can work as well as chemo and wanted to start there.   He said there are lots of different estrogen blocking drugs that can help.  I thought the same thing that you are thinking...it seems so simple...but after 10 years on an estrogen blocking drug with stable mets, I'm a believer.  If you do some research on estrogen blockers, you'll see why they can be very effective for estrogen + breast cancer.
